report_title: Chipping & Grinding Equipment Manufacturing Industry Research
executive_summary: The Chipping and Grinding Equipment Manufacturing industry manufactures commercial-use equipment that is primarily used to process wood into wood chips, wood shavings and sawdust. These products are mainly employed by the forestry sector and recycling facilities to produce wood-based products for paper manufacturing, agricultural purposes, landscaping and energy sources. This industry has experienced volatile conditions over the five years to 2021. The past five years have been characterized by challenging international trade conditions, a sharp decline and a surge in residential construction as a result of the global outbreak of COVID-19 (coronavirus). Overall, industry revenue is expected to increase an annualized 1.7% to reach an estimated $309.5 million, with the industry declining 7.1% in 2021 alone as residential construction demand spikes.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The forestry sector represents the largest source of demand for industry products. For example, logging companies and timber service companies typically use commercial-use wood chippers to clear large sections of Timberland.

As construction markets collapsed in the United States due to the economic crisis, the Chipping and Grinding Equipment Manufacturing industry suffered a massive decline in revenue, which was repeated in 2020 as a result of the coronavirus, indicating how sensitive this industry is to levels of overall construction activity which was severely disrupted in 2020.

However, the subsequent rebound in residential construction, which has increased an annualized 4.7% in 2020 and an expected 8.0% in 2021, has helped industry revenue recover from sharp drops. Since industry products tend to be large-scale capital investments, consumers usually finance machinery that can run into the hundreds of thousands of dollars. However, historically low interest rates over the five years to 2021 have aided downstream industries' investment.

Over the past five years, construction has played an important role in the growth of this industry. During this period, housing starts rose at an annualized rate of 4.5%, which has bolstered demand for wood chippers and grinders used to create the chips and fibers that are integral to making products such as oriented strand board (OSB) and other particle boards used in construction.

Furthermore, industry revenue also benefited from increasing demand for wood chippers used by waste treatment facilities for processing wood waste and using wood chips as an alternative source of energy. Biomass (wood) can be used as an alternative energy source.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next five years, a slowdown in residential construction activity is expected to drag on industry growth, while an acceleration and return to growth in nonresidential construction activity is anticipated to support the industry.

Demand for wood chippers and grinders is also dependent on demand for renewable energy from biomass (wood) sources. With increased demand for biomass as an alternative energy source and decreasing space in landfills, demand for wood chippers and grinders from waste treatment facilities is expected to rise, favorably affecting industry revenue.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures large-scale chippers and grinders for trees, logs and other brush. These large-scale machines are capable of processing one whole tree at a time.

threats: Demand from sawmills and wood production

key_trends: The forestry sector represents the largest source of demand for industry products
Demand from major downstream markets helped maintain revenue and support profit
Despite a weakening dollar, industry imports are expected to marginally increase
An acceleration and return to growth in nonresidential construction activity is anticipated to support the industry
A slowdown in residential construction activity is expected to drag on industry growth
Demand for products is expected to rise in line with demand for biomass as an energy source
The past five years have been characterized by challenging international trade conditions

market_segmentation.segment_description: Exports make up a relatively marginal share of revenue and are anticipated to decline significantly over the five years to 2021.
Wholesalers are estimated to form the primary market for industry products, acting as a liaison between manufacturers and potential buyers.
Timber, logging and sawmill industries demand wood-processing equipment as key capital inputs into operations. Demand from this segment is expected to rise over the five years to 2021.
The recycling segment is estimated to be the fastest-growing downstream market, driven by demand for alternative energy sources and increased efficiencies at landfills.

products_and_services.product_description: Chippers range from portable units to whole-tree chippers designed to output into a semitrailer. Drum chippers are a larger kind of chipper.
Grinders come in horizontal and tub forms. Horizontal grinders take in debris via conveyor belt, while tub grinders take in materials from above.
Other equipment includes flails, debarkers, attachments, parts and accessories. This segment is expected to decline as customers purchase newer equipment.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand from timber industries benefited greatly from renewed housing growth.
Recycling facilities have remained a strong source of demand over the past five years, with strong consumer demand for products made with recycled goods driving demand for wood-processing equipment.
Since industry products are usually very expensive and are large capital investments for consumers, interest rates play a significant role in demand.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Industry exports rose mostly as a result of large increases in 2018 and 2018 due to the impending North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) negotiations and reorganization into The United States, Mexico, Canada Agreement.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region has the highest concentration of establishments at around 25.5%, while the population percentage is relatively lower.
The West region follows with approximately 10.5% of establishments, and the population percentage appears to be slightly higher than the establishment percentage.
The Plains region has around 16.6% of establishments, but the population percentage seems lower.
The Southwest region has a lower percentage of establishments compared to its population percentage.
The Southeast region has a lower percentage of establishments compared to its population percentage.
The Mid-Atlantic region has relatively lower percentages of both establishments and population in this industry.
The Rocky Mountains region has relatively lower percentages of both establishments and population in this industry.
The New England region has relatively lower percentages of both establishments and population in this industry.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Chipping and Grinding Equipment Manufacturing industry exhibits a moderate level of regulation. Most importantly, the passing of legislation that mandates increased use of recycled materials or biofuels at manufacturing facilities on local, state and federal levels positively affects demand for this industry's equipment.

barriers_points.barrier_title: High market share concentration among top players
barriers_points.barrier_description: The Chipping and Grinding Equipment Manufacturing industry poses high barriers to entry through the high market share concentration estimated to exist among the top three companies.

New entrants would likely contend with prohibitive costs and long lead times in developing comparable sales networks to the vast distribution networks that operate worldwide for incumbents like Vermeer, Morbark and Bandit.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Economies of scale of large players
barriers_points.barrier_description: The sheer size of the large incumbent companies enables them to employ economies of scale that lower operating costs per unit made through bulk purchases of inputs.
Large players have high brand recognition and loyalty among downstream industries that new competitors would find difficult to achieve, given the costly nature of the equipment.

basis_points.basis_title: Price is an important but not the most important factor
basis_points.basis_description: Commercial chipping and grinding equipment is expensive, with medium-to-large units costing hundreds of thousands of dollars. Accordingly, the price differential from one company to another is insignificant considering that potential buyers are already prepared to make such large capital outlays.

basis_points.basis_title: Individual machine capabilities are key factors
basis_points.basis_description: Individual machine capabilities such as horsepower, fuel efficiency, processing rates, attachment versatility, safety features, digital controls and portability factor heavily into purchase decisions and form the main bases of competition.

basis_points.basis_title: User experience and customer service drive brand loyalty
basis_points.basis_description: User experience with each unit and the manufacturer's customer service department helps develop or erode brand loyalty.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 3 companies account for over 60% market share
concentration_points.concentration_description: Based on IBISWorld analysis, the top three companies are estimated to account for over 60.0% of industry revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: In 2021 wages as a share of revenue are estimated to account for 12.3% of revenue, which is an increase from levels of 11.8% in 2016. Though industry wages are up marginally for the period, wage pressure is anticipated to decline over the next five years.

The cost of materials represents the largest cost for the Chipping and Grinding Equipment Manufacturing industry. In 2021, IBISWorld estimates that material purchases will represent 54.1% of revenue, which is a decrease from 2016 levels.

Industry players, especially large companies, invested heavily in capital machinery to automate work-processes and increase output. As a result, this industry exhibits a moderate degree of depreciation. Industry depreciation charges account for an estimated 2.4% of industry revenue in 2021.

Industry marketing charges are low, accounting for an estimated 0.2% of industry revenue in 2021. Overall, since there is such a slim field of manufacturers to choose from, advertising and marketing does little to attract customers outside of geographic markets.

Since industry establishments require large manufacturing facilities, the majority of companies own their plants, as opposed to renting. In 2021 rent payments are expected to account for 0.4% of industry revenue.

This industry requires electricity-intense equipment such as welders to manufacture large pieces of industrial equipment. Overall, utilities costs are expected to account for 0.6% of industry revenue in 2021.
Other costs account for 23.9% of industry revenue in 2021 and can include items such as administrative costs and fees, debt service payments, research and development and employee benefits.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: IBISWorld analysis reveals the Chipping and Grinding Equipment Manufacturing industry exhibits a medium level of capital intensity. The average industry player employs nearly 35 workers, mostly performing tasks such as research, development and design, in addition to quality control and testing functions.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Over the five years to 2021, IBISWorld analysis reveals the Chipping and Grinding Equipment Manufacturing industry exhibits a high level of revenue volatility. Volatility in this industry can be attributed to several factors, including downstream demand and the health of the overall economy.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: There are two main varieties of technological innovation at play in the Chipping and Grinding Equipment Manufacturing industry. The first involves the processes used in actually making the various machinery included in the industry.

FAQs.question: Do your sales depend on the overall health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Demand for industry products tends to follow residential construction activity and forestry-related industry performance. When the economy is performing well, the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates, increasing borrowing costs for industry operators.

FAQs.answer: Diversified producers will exhibit lower degrees of revenue volatility, aiding profitability. Non-diversified producers will be more subject to output price fluctuations, hindering profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to excess revenue volatility?
FAQs.answer: Producers that enter into long-term supply contracts with downstream customers will exhibit more stable revenue. Producers that exercise input-price and supply management will have a better time planning next year's crop, boosting potential profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to key buying and selling markets?
FAQs.answer: Producers located in proximity to key selling markets will exhibit lower transportation costs and higher profitability. Producers located in proximity to key input suppliers will exhibit lower purchase costs and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging the latest technologies?
FAQs.answer: By using electronic order tracking, manufacturers can better track supply chain management, boosting potential for profitability. Operators that do not adopt the latest technologies may become uncompetitive and be forced to exit the industry.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to reduce wage costs via automation?
FAQs.answer: Labor costs can be reduced by adopting auto welding technologies. Operators leveraging the latest technologies will exhibit higher operating efficiency and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all occupational health and safety requirements are upheld?
FAQs.answer: Compliant producers will exhibit lower insurance premiums and costs, boosting profitability. Noncompliant producers will be subject to insurance cost increases, undercutting profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to adapt to shifting environmental regulations?
FAQs.answer: Producers with a penchant for environmentally friendly and organic produce may be favored by the public, Noncompliant producers will be subject to fines and penalties, limiting profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company had any difficulty financing current operations?
FAQs.answer: Producers that enter into long-term supply contracts will have more stable revenue, enduring price declines better and protecting against profit margin volatility. Manufacturers that adopt electronic inventory management software will exhibit lower purchase costs and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: How does your profit margin compare to those of your biggest competitors?
FAQs.answer: Producers that adopt the latest technologies will exhibit higher operating efficiencies. Producers that enter into long-term supply contracts will exhibit lower revenue volatility and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? What range does your company have in terms of viable operating area?
FAQs.answer: Successful manufacturers locate close to raw material deposits and the main sources of demand.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain product quality? Do you have systems in place to keep standards high and continually updating?
FAQs.answer: The ability to control quality and minimize faulty products reaching the market will help increase brand loyalty through perceived reliability.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changing environmental regulations? How do you adapt to changes due to such regulations?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers contend with a range of regulations regarding the generation and disposal of hazardous wastes. Failure to meet compliance can increase operating costs.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in the TWI? How has this affected your company? How will you mitigate this threat going forward?
FAQs.answer: Industry revenue is correlated with trends in the trade-weighted index.

FAQs.answer: Loggers use chippers and grinders to clear timberland and process wood in the field.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your sales are to sawmills?
FAQs.answer: Sawmills use industry equipment to manufacture wood chips and sawdust, benefiting the industry.
